trans-unit.target: No photo clubs seem to be currently loaded. Try dragging down the Photo Clubs screen to reload the default clubs.
trans-unit.note: Hint to the user if the database returns zero PhotoClubs.
Header of section of Who's Who screen
Section title on Readme page.

trans-unit.source: This app showcases selected photos by the members of photo clubs. Ex-members of photo clubs can optionally also be included.
trans-unit.target: This app showcases selected photos by the members of photo clubs. Ex-members of photo clubs can optionally also be included.
trans-unit.note: First paragraph in Waalre section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: It does this in a _uniform_ way across all these photographers and participating clubs. For the target audience, this uniformity avoids having to find the websites and discovering how to navigate each unique site.
trans-unit.target: It does this in a _uniform_ way across all these photographers and participating clubs. For the target audience, this uniformity avoids having to find the websites and discovering how to navigate each unique site.
trans-unit.note: Second paragraph in Waalre section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: The app does not try to replace individual or club _websites_, or try to replace invididual or club social media presence: its only focus is to present all the images in an easily accesible way with minimal distraction. The app can display links to external sites for additional information.
trans-unit.target: The app does not try to replace individual or club _websites_, or try to replace invididual or club social media presence: its only focus is to present all the images in an easily accesible way with minimal distraction. The app can display links to external sites for additional information.
trans-unit.note: Third paragraph in Waalre section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: The app was originally named _Fotogroep (Photo Club) Waalre_ after an eponymous 20-person photo club in The Netherlands. The word 'Hub' in the new name stresses the app's current support for _multiple_ photo clubs, and the hope that the app can strengthen ties between clubs, and photographers by making their work easier to discover.
trans-unit.target: The app was originally named _Fotogroep (Photo Club) Waalre_ after an eponymous 20-person photo club in The Netherlands. The word 'Hub' in the new name stresses the app's current support for _multiple_ photo clubs, and the hope that the app can strengthen ties between clubs, and photographers by making their work easier to discover.
trans-unit.note: Fourth paragraph in Waalre section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: Support for multiple photo clubs requires the ability to display a list of clubs, their members and a series of selected photos per member.
trans-unit.target: Support for multiple photo clubs requires the ability to display a list of clubs, their members and a series of selected photos per member.
trans-unit.note: Fifth paragraph in Waalre section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: Multi-club support also implies that individual clubs do their _data maintenance_: providing and maintaining the images and the associated lists. We believe that central support should be limited to maintaining the app only - leaving the maintenance of the data to the clubs that provide the images. The app's [GitHub site](https://GitHub.com/vdhamer/Photo-Club-Hub#readme) explains the interim approach for onboardng clubs and the plans how to enable the clubs to do this themselves with minimal software expertise.
trans-unit.target: Multi-club support also implies that individual clubs do their _data maintenance_: providing and maintaining the images and the associated lists. We believe that central support should be limited to maintaining the app only - leaving the maintenance of the data to the clubs that provide the images. The app's [GitHub site](https://GitHub.com/vdhamer/Photo-Club-Hub#readme) explains the interim approach for onboardng clubs and the plans how to enable the clubs to do this themselves with minimal software expertise.
trans-unit.note: Sixth paragraph in Waalre section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: As mentioned, the goal of this app is to showcase curated work of members of photo clubs.
trans-unit.target: As mentioned, the goal of this app is to showcase curated work of members of photo clubs.
trans-unit.note: First paragraph in The App on Readme page

trans-unit.source: The main screen of the app shown a series of ***photo clubs***. Each photo club, in turn, contains a series of member ***portfolios***. The portfolios contain the actual images.
trans-unit.target: The main screen of the app shown a series of ***photo clubs***. Each photo club, in turn, contains a series of member ***portfolios***. The portfolios contain the actual images.
trans-unit.note: Second paragraph in The App on Readme page

trans-unit.source: Each portfolio thus covers the subset of the photographer's work that is associated with that photo club. A photographer could have more than one portfolio in this app, if the photographer was (at some point in time) a member of multiple photo clubs.
trans-unit.target: Each portfolio thus covers the subset of the photographer's work that is associated with that photo club. A photographer could have more than one portfolio in this app, if the photographer was (at some point in time) a member of multiple photo clubs.
trans-unit.note: Third paragraph in The App on Readme page

trans-unit.source: Each portfolio is shown in chronological order, with the latest work shown first, and typically spans multiple years.
trans-unit.target: Each portfolio is shown in chronological order, with the latest work shown first, and typically spans multiple years.
trans-unit.note: Fourth paragraph in The App on Readme page

trans-unit.source: We try to show the portfolios with **minimal distraction**. Web sites are often less optimal for this because they need to show browser controls (e.g., an address bar or tabs) and serve multiple purposes (e.g., show club news or contact information).
trans-unit.target: We try to show the portfolios with **minimal distraction**. Web sites are often less optimal for this because they need to show browser controls (e.g., an address bar or tabs) and serve multiple purposes (e.g., show club news or contact information).
trans-unit.note: Fifth paragraph in The App on Readme page

trans-unit.source: For Photo Club Waalre, we chose to also include the work of former club members. By default, former members are not visible, but you can configure the app to show them.
trans-unit.target: For Photo Club Waalre, we chose to also include the work of former club members. By default, former members are not visible, but you can configure the app to show them.
trans-unit.note: Sixth paragraph in the App on Readme page

trans-unit.source: Contact us (github@vdhamer.com) if you are interested in adding support for your photo club.
trans-unit.target: Contact us (github@vdhamer.com) if you are interested in adding support for your photo club.
trans-unit.note: Seventh paragraph in the App on Readme page

trans-unit.source: __Web sites__ We regularly add features to the app. This requires some care, because we still want to maintain our focus on providing an optimal viewing experience. The app therefore explicitly does _not_ aim to replace existing websites, but instead provides links to these websites.
trans-unit.target: __Web sites__ We regularly add features to the app. This requires some care, because we still want to maintain our focus on providing an optimal viewing experience. The app therefore explicitly does _not_ aim to replace existing websites, but instead provides links to these websites.
trans-unit.note: First paragraph in The Features section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: __Languages__ The app supports English and Dutch. iOS automatically selects the app's language based on your device’s language settings (_Settings > General > Language & Region > Preferred Language Order_). iOS also allows you to overrule this choice per app (_Settings > Photo Club Waalre > Language_).
trans-unit.target: __Languages__ The app supports English and Dutch. iOS automatically selects the app's language based on your device’s language settings (_Settings > General > Language & Region > Preferred Language Order_). iOS also allows you to overrule this choice per app (_Settings > Photo Club Waalre > Language_).
trans-unit.note: Second paragraph in The Features section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: __Deleting__ On the Portfolio page, you can swipe to ***Delete*** a member from the list. Don't worry - if the person is still a club member, that person will reappear the next time the app synchronizes its local data with online data. This swiping can be useful to remove members who are no longer on the online data members lists. In any case, swipe as much as you like (after all, it just might be therapeutical).
trans-unit.target: __Deleting__ On the Portfolio page, you can swipe to ***Delete*** a member from the list. Don't worry - if the person is still a club member, that person will reappear the next time the app synchronizes its local data with online data. This swiping can be useful to remove members who are no longer on the online data members lists. In any case, swipe as much as you like (after all, it just might be therapeutical).
trans-unit.note: Third paragraph in The Features section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: __Roadmap__ By clicking on the above button you can (anonymously) vote for improvements you would like in future versions of this app. You can only vote once for any particular improvement.
trans-unit.target: __Roadmap__ By clicking on the above button you can (anonymously) vote for improvements you would like in future versions of this app. You can only vote once for any particular improvement.
trans-unit.note: Fourth paragraph in The Features section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: When the app opens, it shows a large image corresponding to the app’s icon. If you tap somewhere ***inside*** the image, it zooms out to show the full image representing how digital cameras see color.
trans-unit.target: When the app opens, it shows a large image corresponding to the app’s icon. If you tap somewhere ***inside*** the image, it zooms out to show the full image representing how digital cameras see color.
trans-unit.note: First paragraph in Prelude section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: This involves a [Bayer color filter array](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayer_filter) that filters the light per pixel. The filter array is shown here superimposed on a colorful photo.
trans-unit.target: This involves a [Bayer color filter array](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayer_filter) that filters the light per pixel. The filter array is shown here superimposed on a colorful photo.
trans-unit.note: Second paragraph in Prelude section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: Tapping ***inside*** the image allows you to zoom in or out to your heart's content. Tapping ***outside*** the image area ends the animation. You can trigger the animation again by restarting the app. A single tap ***outside*** the image allows you to skip the animation entirely.
trans-unit.target: Tapping ***inside*** the image allows you to zoom in or out to your heart's content. Tapping ***outside*** the image area ends the animation. You can trigger the animation again by restarting the app. A single tap ***outside*** the image allows you to skip the animation entirely.
trans-unit.note: Third paragraph in Prelude section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: The app runs on iPhone and iPad and requires iOS 16.4 or higher. Most iOS users tend to upgrade to the latest possible iOS version, which means that the app supports devices made in the last 5 or 6 years.
trans-unit.target: The app runs on iPhone and iPad and requires iOS 16.4 or higher. Most iOS users tend to upgrade to the latest possible iOS version, which means that the app supports devices made in the last 5 or 6 years.
trans-unit.note: First paragraph SupportedPlatforms section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: The app uses various Apple software technologies including Swift (a programming language), SwiftUI (a user interface framework), Core Data (local data storage), Metal (graphics acceleration), concurrency (for fetching data), and animations.
trans-unit.target: The app uses various Apple software technologies including Swift (a programming language), SwiftUI (a user interface framework), Core Data (local data storage), Metal (graphics acceleration), concurrency (for fetching data), and animations.
trans-unit.note: Second paragraph SupportedPlatforms section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: The benefit of an iOS focus is that it allows the developers to focus on functionality rather than cross-platform and cross-version interoperability issues.
trans-unit.target: The benefit of an iOS focus is that it allows the developers to focus on functionality rather than cross-platform and cross-version interoperability issues.
trans-unit.note: Third paragraph SupportedPlatforms section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: The drawback, however, is the lack of Android support, because the Android universe has its own set of software technologies. Apps that choose to support multiple platforms require more development effort and often contain more technical compromises.
trans-unit.target: The drawback, however, is the lack of Android support, because the Android universe has its own set of software technologies. Apps that choose to support multiple platforms require more development effort and often contain more technical compromises.
trans-unit.note: Fourth paragraph SupportedPlatforms section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: There is another perspective on not targeting Android anytime soon: it implies the app cannot contain any essentially functionality for which there is no alternative. So, again, the app cannot replace a club's website.
trans-unit.target: There is another perspective on not targeting Android anytime soon: it implies the app cannot contain any essentially functionality for which there is no alternative. So, again, the app cannot replace a club's website.
trans-unit.note: Fifth paragraph SupportedPlatforms section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: To put the app's device support into perspective, consider the top-6 software environments. The top-6 platforms are, in [largest-first order](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7S9PBgS8HS8): web, Android, Windows, iOS, iPadOS. Only the very largest apps (like MS Word, Twitter, Minecraft, Chrome) manage to cover the full range. But many well-known apps choose to focus their resources: Photoshop (Windows, MacOS, iPadOS), WhatsApp (iOS, Android, web - kind of), Pokémon Go (Android, iOS, iPadOS - kind of). So, covering three of the top-six is a decent enough score for now.
trans-unit.target: To put the app's device support into perspective, consider the top-6 software environments. The top-6 platforms are, in [largest-first order](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7S9PBgS8HS8): web, Android, Windows, iOS, iPadOS. Only the very largest apps (like MS Word, Twitter, Minecraft, Chrome) manage to cover the full range. But many well-known apps choose to focus their resources: Photoshop (Windows, MacOS, iPadOS), WhatsApp (iOS, Android, web - kind of), Pokémon Go (Android, iOS, iPadOS - kind of). So, covering three of the top-six is a decent enough score for now.
trans-unit.note: Sixth paragraph SupportedPlatforms section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: You can find this app on GitHub. This allows other software developers to contribute. Getting more developers speeds things up somewhat, but also gives fresh ideas and promotes continuity.
trans-unit.target: You can find this app on GitHub. This allows other software developers to contribute. Getting more developers speeds things up somewhat, but also gives fresh ideas and promotes continuity.
trans-unit.note: First paragraph Developers section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: Welcome contributions include adding features, code improvements, ideas on architecture and interface definition, and possibly even a backend.
trans-unit.target: Welcome contributions include adding features, code improvements, ideas on architecture and interface definition, and possibly even a backend.
trans-unit.note: Second paragraph Developers section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: Contributions that don't require coding are also very welcome: beta testing via TestFlight, feature requests, translations, SVG icons, sound effects, and maybe UI/UX design.
trans-unit.target: Contributions that don't require coding are also very welcome: beta testing via TestFlight, feature requests, translations, SVG icons, sound effects, and maybe UI/UX design.
trans-unit.note: Third paragraph Developers section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: A central design challenge for a next stage will be to provide a clean, standardized interface to retrieve data per photo club. The interface is needed to load the data, but also keeps the data within the app up to date. After all, membership data and portfolios change regularly. The current interface is essentially a plug-in design with an adaptor per photo club. This needs to be replaced by a standard data interface to avoid having to extend the source code whenever a new club comes aboard.
trans-unit.target: A central design challenge for a next stage will be to provide a clean, standardized interface to retrieve data per photo club. The interface is needed to load the data, but also keeps the data within the app up to date. After all, membership data and portfolios change regularly. The current interface is essentially a plug-in design with an adaptor per photo club. This needs to be replaced by a standard data interface to avoid having to extend the source code whenever a new club comes aboard.
trans-unit.note: Fourth paragraph Developers section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: The app currently uses a software module per club. That module loads membership and portfolio data from the club’s server and merges it into the in-app database. For Photo Club Waalre, the membership data is read from a HTML table on a password protected part of the club’s [website](https://www.FotogroepWaalre.nl). The portfolios use a somewhat more robust solution: they are read from XML files generated by a Lightroom Web plug-in called [JuiceBox-Pro](https://www.juicebox.net/tour/). Thus portfolios are created and managed as Lightroom *collections*. These collections are then uploaded to the webserver with a single _Upload_ click (thus triggering JuiceBox-Pro) where they can be downloaded by the app.
trans-unit.target: The app currently uses a software module per club. That module loads membership and portfolio data from the club’s server and merges it into the in-app database. For Photo Club Waalre, the membership data is read from a HTML table on a password protected part of the club’s [website](https://www.FotogroepWaalre.nl). The portfolios use a somewhat more robust solution: they are read from XML files generated by a Lightroom Web plug-in called [JuiceBox-Pro](https://www.juicebox.net/tour/). Thus portfolios are created and managed as Lightroom *collections*. These collections are then uploaded to the webserver with a single _Upload_ click (thus triggering JuiceBox-Pro) where they can be downloaded by the app.
trans-unit.note: Fifth paragraph Developers section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: Software developers or other volunteers who are willing to help can contact us via github@vdhamer.com. Regarding the required level of development experience: you should be good to go if you have created a complete SwiftUI app before. Alternatively, an experienced developer who is learning SwiftUI would also fit the bill. Recommended courses for learning SwiftUI are Hacking with Swift's practical [100 days of SwiftUI](https://www.hackingwithswift.com/100/swiftui/) or Stanford's fast paced and more academic online [CS193p course](https://cs193p.sites.stanford.edu).
trans-unit.target: Software developers or other volunteers who are willing to help can contact us via github@vdhamer.com. Regarding the required level of development experience: you should be good to go if you have created a complete SwiftUI app before. Alternatively, an experienced developer who is learning SwiftUI would also fit the bill. Recommended courses for learning SwiftUI are Hacking with Swift's practical [100 days of SwiftUI](https://www.hackingwithswift.com/100/swiftui/) or Stanford's fast paced and more academic online [CS193p course](https://cs193p.sites.stanford.edu).
trans-unit.note: Sixth paragraph Developers section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: As an intro for developers, here is an informal tour of the ***model***. The model is a [schema](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database_schema) or information model in the database sense, or “Model“ in the sense of the [Model-View-ViewModel](https://www.hackingwithswift.com/books/ios-swiftui/introducing-mvvm-into-your-swiftui-project) design pattern. The app uses a Swift-style MVVM design, meaning model data is stored in structs rather than in classes.
trans-unit.target: As an intro for developers, here is an informal tour of the ***model***. The model is a [schema](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Database_schema) or information model in the database sense, or “Model“ in the sense of the [Model-View-ViewModel](https://www.hackingwithswift.com/books/ios-swiftui/introducing-mvvm-into-your-swiftui-project) design pattern. The app uses a Swift-style MVVM design, meaning model data is stored in structs rather than in classes.
trans-unit.note: First paragraph Model section of Readme page

trans-unit.source: The model: every **PhotoClub** has **Members** of various types (current, former, etc.), while some Members have a formal role like chairman within the PhotoClub. Some of **Photographer**'s data (like name and birthday) are unrelated to being a Member of a PhotoClub. **Portfolios** represent the body of work of a Photographer in the context of a PhotoClub. A Portfolio contains **Images**, but an Image could be in multiple Portfolios depending on where the Image was shared. Member and Portfolio can technically be considered synonyms from a modeling perspective: we create exactly one Portfolio for each PhotoClub that a Photographer joined. They are thus a single table in the database.
trans-unit.target: The model: every **PhotoClub** has **Members** of various types (current, former, etc.), while some Members have a formal role like chairman within the PhotoClub. Some of **Photographer**'s data (like name and birthday) are unrelated to being a Member of a PhotoClub. **Portfolios** represent the body of work of a Photographer in the context of a PhotoClub. A Portfolio contains **Images**, but an Image could be in multiple Portfolios depending on where the Image was shared. Member and Portfolio can technically be considered synonyms from a modeling perspective: we create exactly one Portfolio for each PhotoClub that a Photographer joined. They are thus a single table in the database.
trans-unit.note: Second paragraph Model section of Readme page

trans-unit.id: This page lists all the photographers that this app knows about. A photographer has one or more clickable image thumbnails below the photographer's name. Clicking on any thumbnail leads to the images associated with one particular photo club. The thumbnails can be scrolled horizontally (if there are many of them on one line).
trans-unit.source: This page lists all the photographers that this app knows about. A photographer has one or more clickable image thumbnails below the photographer's name. Clicking on any thumbnail leads to the images associated with one particular photo club. The thumbnails can be scrolled horizontally (if there are many of them on one line).
trans-unit.target: This page lists all the photographers that this app knows about. A photographer has one or more clickable image thumbnails below the photographer's name. Clicking on any thumbnail leads to the images associated with one particular photo club. The thumbnails can be scrolled horizontally (if there are many of them on one line).
trans-unit.note: Shown in gray at the bottom of the Photographers page.
